description.summary: Religious or spiritual practice to expel demons or spirits from possessed individuals, performed across multiple faith traditions including Catholic, Protestant, Islamic, Hindu, Buddhist, and Jewish practices.
description.full: Exorcism is a religious or spiritual practice to expel demons, spirits, or other entities from individuals believed to be possessed. Major traditions include Catholic exorcism (Roman Ritual, authorized priest required), Protestant deliverance ministries, Islamic ruqya (Qur'an recitation), and Hindu, Buddhist, and Jewish variations. The Catholic procedure involves an authorized priest, bishop permission, Rite of Exorcism with prayers, commands, holy water, and crucifix. Famous exorcists include Father Gabriele Amorth (Vatican exorcist claiming 60,000+ exorcisms). Famous cases include the Anneliese Michel tragedy (died during exorcism, 1976) and Roland Doe (1949). Modern Church position requires psychiatric evaluation first, considers genuine possession extremely rare, and takes cautious approach. Dangers include documented deaths (Anneliese Michel and others) and delayed psychiatric treatment. Scientific view: ritual may provide psychological relief through placebo effect, but psychiatric treatment is more effective. This is a sacred practice in multiple religions requiring cultural sensitivity.

etymology.origin: From Greek 'exorkismos' meaning 'binding by oath,' from 'exorkizein' (to bind by oath, adjure)
etymology.meaning: To command or adjure (a spirit) to depart

requirements: Evidence of genuine possession (not mental illness)
major_traditions.status: Active; Church continues to train exorcists

requirements: Some require training, others do not
Knowledge of Qur'an and Islamic jurisprudence

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient practice across multiple religions; exorcism accounts in Bible, Qur'an, Hindu texts, Buddhist scriptures
origins.earliest_accounts: Biblical accounts of Jesus performing exorcisms; ancient Jewish practices; pre-Islamic Arabian practices
origins.development: Formalized over centuries in different religious traditions

timeline.significance: Catholic Church formally codifies exorcism ritual
Case that inspired The Exorcist; increased public awareness
67 sessions over 10 months; woman died; criminal trial of priests and parents
De Exorcismis et Supplicationibus Quibusdam - modernized procedures
Catholic Church reports increased demand; more priests trained

history.modern_era: Exorcism remains active across multiple religious traditions. Catholic Church continues training exorcists while emphasizing caution. Protestant deliverance ministries active. Islamic ruqya widely practiced. Medical community emphasizes psychiatric treatment. Cultural sensitivity increasingly recognized.

famous_practitioners.name: Father Gabriele Amorth
famous_practitioners.role: Chief exorcist of Diocese of Rome
famous_practitioners.contribution: Claimed to perform over 60,000 exorcisms; prominent advocate
famous_practitioners.notes: Controversial figure; claims disputed by skeptics

famous_practitioners.name: Father Malachi Martin
famous_practitioners.contribution: Wrote 'Hostage to the Devil' detailing exorcism accounts
famous_practitioners.notes: Popular author; claims subject to skepticism

notable.name: Anneliese Michel
notable.description: 67 exorcism sessions over 10 months. Woman had epilepsy and psychiatric conditions. Died of malnutrition and dehydration. Priests and parents convicted of negligent homicide.
notable.significance: Demonstrates extreme danger of exorcism when psychiatric treatment needed
sources: Goodman, F. (2005). The Exorcism of Anneliese Michel

notable.name: Roland Doe (pseudonym)
notable.description: 14-year-old boy underwent exorcism. Case inspired William Peter Blatty's novel 'The Exorcist.' Individual lived normal life afterward. Later investigations suggest possible psychiatric issues and hoax elements.
sources: Opsasnick, M. (1999). Investigation in Strange Magazine

documented_risks.description: Treating mental illness as possession delays proper medical care
Withholding food, water, or medical care

modern_safeguards: Recognition that genuine possession is extremely rare

scientific_perspective.view: No evidence that exorcism expels actual demons or spirits

explanations.description: Ritual provides psychological relief; expectation of cure creates improvement
Attention and support from community provides comfort
Actual psychiatric care addresses underlying conditions
Some conditions improve over time regardless of intervention

scientific_perspective.consensus: Psychiatric conditions require psychiatric treatment. Exorcism may provide cultural/religious comfort but is not substitute for medical care.

cultural.sensitivity_note: ⚠️ CULTURAL SENSITIVITY: Exorcism is a sacred practice in multiple world religions. This documentation respects religious beliefs while presenting medical perspectives.

religious_significance.importance: Central spiritual practice in some traditions; addresses fundamental beliefs about good, evil, and spiritual warfare
religious_significance.variations: Practices vary significantly by tradition; understanding cultural context essential
religious_significance.respect: Medical professionals should approach with cultural competence while ensuring patient safety

current_position: Psychiatric evaluation required before exorcism considered
Medical treatment continues alongside any spiritual intervention
Only authorized priests may perform major exorcism
catholic_church.training: Church continues to train exorcists; courses offered in Rome and elsewhere
catholic_church.reported_demand: Some reports of increased requests for exorcism in 21st century

best_practices: Cultural competence in mental health care
Collaboration between medical and religious communities when appropriate
Education about psychiatric conditions in culturally appropriate ways
